intro.description: This Tutorial will show you how to view NeXus files

item.title: Open DEXplore Perspective
item.description: To visualise data effectively the DExplore Perspective is the best perspective to use, change to this now.

item.title: Create a new Project containing example data
item.description:
Create a new data project if you don't already have one from the Diamond Example Data.
To do this use File -> New -> Project, and then select Data -> Data Project and click on Next
Browse to the Directory /dls/sci-scratch/ExampleData and click OK
The Data project should appear in the Project Explorer.

item.title: Open a Nexus Scan
item.description:
In the Example Data Project there is some NeXus data, navigate to its location which is:
data -> NeXus
Now Double Click on the file 2495.nxs to open it for displaying the data.
The file should have now opened in the Editor area (previously blank) and show a list of all the file metadata and an entry dataset.
The file can be browsed through the NeXus Editor (Editor view) by clicking on the down-arrow left of entry1 (unfolding the NeXus sub elements). It can also be browsed through the Project Explorer by unfolding the NeXus file itself.

item.title: Plotting the Data From the File
item.description:
To plot some simple data from the file, simply double click on the name of the data which you would like to see, in this case pick EDXD_Element_03, one of the sub element of entry1.
Alternatively, you can single click on that same data from the unfolded file in the Project Explorer. Once this is selected you should see the a single peaked plot with two discontinuities appear in the Dataset Plot View.

item.title: Multi dimensional data plotting
item.description:
The Dataset Inspector (Data axes selection part) is reporting that the data it has access to is 3 dimensional. This means we can select to view the information in a variety of ways.
First let's look at the images which have been collected. To do this you need to change to the 2D image mode in the Dataset Inspector; this is done by selecting the 2D image tab in the top right section of the view, you may need to expand the options if you cannot see it immediately by using the '>>' part to the right of existing tabs.
The NeXus image should now have appeared in the DataSet Plot. To change which Image is being viewed, you can use the dataset slicing section at the bottom of the Dataset Inspector view. There is one slider bar which is not fully across, with 'edxd_q' next to it. Drag this bar about, and you will see the image change in the Dataset Plot view.

item.title: Surface Plotting
item.description:
Lets look at one other way of plotting the data. Instead of '2D image' tab, select '2D Surface'
The same tools are available, just you are now viewing a surface plot, and not an image.

item.title: Stack Plotting
item.description:
Finally lets look at one other way of plotting the data. Select '1D Stack Plot'. This displays all the data plots 'stacked' together.
With edxd_q as a x-axis and dim:2 as a z-axis, pick the zoom tool (zoom button on Dataset Plot) and zoom on region of interests (the irregularities on the peak of the plot).
In the Dataset Inspector drag the dim:1 slider to see the plot stack change.
Set the z-axis to dim:1 and drag the dim:2 slider to see the plot stack change.
Check the in 3D mode of the 1D Stack Plot to have a 3D view of your stacked plots.

item.title: Done
item.description: This tutorial has taken you through some basics of looking at an example NeXus data file. As a reminder, the slicing and visualisation tools used here would work on any multidimensional dataset (NeXus files being such possible datasets).
